data.title: Emmy Predictions 2024: FX Leads Drama and Comedy Races With ‚ÄòShogun‚Äô and ‚ÄòThe Bear‚Äô While ‚ÄòBaby Reindeer‚Äô Could Walk Away With Limited Series
data.meta_description: 2024 Emmys predictions for every category include "Abbott Elementary," "The Crown," "The Bear," "Fargo," "True Detective" and "Avatar."
data.text:
Variety‚Äòs Awards Circuit is the home for all awards news and related content throughout the year. It features the official predictions for the Oscars, Emmys, Grammys, and Tony Awards, curated by Variety senior awards editor Clayton Davis. The prediction pages reflect the current standings in the race and do not reflect personal preferences for any individual contender. As other formal (and informal) polls suggest, competitions are fluid and subject to change based on buzz and events. Predictions are updated every Thursday.

Visit the prediction pages for the respective ceremonies via the links below:

OSCARS | EMMYS | GRAMMYS | TONYS

2024 Emmy Predictions: All Categories

Weekly Commentary (Updated: Aug. 8, 2024): Emmys done good.

For someone following the pendulum swings of DEI initiatives in Hollywood, the nomination morning of any awards show can be emotionally draining. This year that is not the case. Even though studios have stepped back from their commitments and promises of 2020, members of the Television Academy made significant strides in putting the golden spotlight on a diverse array of nominees. Also exciting is the broader range of series, genres, studios and networks represented.

In the acting races, less than one-third of the nominees are people of color. Still, among 96 nominations bestowed across 16 acting categories, voters nominated 30 people of color, a 20% increase over last year. Although 2022 saw a record-breaking 42 people of color nominated in the acting categories, that resulted in zero wins. This year promises a different outcome.

A historic milestone for Indigenous performers dominated the announcements. Before this year, the late actor August Schellenberg was nominated in the supporting actor limited category as Sitting Bull in the 2007 HBO film ‚ÄúBury My Heart at Wounded Knee,‚Äù and was the only Native American given the nod for acting. Recent Oscar darling Lily Gladstone and former boxing champion Kali Reis join him as the first Indigenous women nominated ‚Äî for ‚ÄúUnder the Bridge‚Äù and ‚ÄúTrue Detective: Night Country,‚Äù respectively. Additionally, D‚ÄôPharaoh Woon-A-Tai, a surprise lead comedy actor inclusion, received long overdue recognition for his role in the final season of FX‚Äôs ‚ÄúReservation Dogs,‚Äù a first for Indigenous actors in any lead acting race.

Although Latino performers made up less than 6% of the acting submissions, five notable actors found love: Selena Gomez (lead comedy actress for ‚ÄúOnly Murders in the Building‚Äù), Sofia Vergara (lead actress limited for ‚ÄúGriselda‚Äù), Liza Col√≥n-Zayas (supporting comedy actress for ‚ÄúThe Bear‚Äù), Nava Mau (supporting actress limited for ‚ÄúBaby Reindeer‚Äù) and N√©stor Carbonell (guest drama actor for ‚ÄúSh≈çgun‚Äù). As an executive producer of ‚ÄúOnly Murders,‚Äù Gomez is now the most Emmy-nominated Latina producer in any series category, with three noms.

Issa L√≥pez, showrunner for ‚ÄúTrue Detective: Night Country,‚Äù received nods for directing, writing and producing the fourth season of the anthology crime drama. She‚Äôs the first Latina nominated for directing and the second for writing, following Ren√© Echevarria in 2005 for ‚ÄúThe 4400.‚Äù

FX‚Äôs historical epic ‚ÄúSh≈çgun,‚Äù the second non-English language series nominated after ‚ÄúSquid Game‚Äù in 2022, delivered the majority of AAPI acting nominees this year: lead actor and actress drama nominees Hiroyuki Sanada and Anna Sawai and supporting players Tadanobu Asano and Takehiro Hira. Alongside Sawai is Maya Erskine from the action drama ‚ÄúMr. and Mrs. Smith‚Äù; they‚Äôre the second and third Asian women nominated in any category after Sandra Oh for ‚ÄúKilling Eve‚Äù (2018-20). Oh is nominated as an executive producer of the TV movie ‚ÄúQuiz Lady,‚Äù alongside co-star Awkwafina and director Jessica Yu.

Black actors saw significant gains. Quinta Brunson, who became the second Black woman to win lead comedy actress last year, earned her third acting nod for ABC‚Äôs ‚ÄúAbbott Elementary.‚Äù Joining her are Ayo Edebiri (‚ÄúThe Bear‚Äù) and Maya Rudolph (‚ÄúLoot‚Äù). The latter was the most nominated performer of the year, with additional noms for voice-over, guest acting and original song. Also, Brunson, Edebiri, Gomez and Rudolph marked the first time women of color dominated any lead acting category.

Salli Richardson-Whitfield, a surprise directing nominee for HBO‚Äôs now-canceled drama ‚ÄúWinning Time: The Rise of the Lakers Dynasty,‚Äù made history as the first Black woman nominated in the category. LGBTQ artists also made strides. Mau of ‚ÄúBaby Reindeer‚Äù is the second transgender actor recognized in the main acting categories after Michaela Ja√© Rodriguez. Other members of the LGBTQ community finding recognition include Bowen Yang (‚ÄúSNL‚Äù), Andrew Scott (‚ÄúRipley‚Äù), Jonathan Bailey (‚ÄúFellow Travelers‚Äù), Matt Bomer (‚ÄúFellow Travelers‚Äù), Sarah Paulson (‚ÄúMr. and Mrs. Smith‚Äù) and Paulson‚Äôs real-life partner, Holland Taylor (‚ÄúThe Morning Show‚Äù).

Despite a more than 33% decrease in overall submissions, Emmy voters took the time to be genuinely inclusive in this first round of the dance. This should further prove that diverse stories and talent will connect with audiences when given the opportunity. Studios should take note of this strong year: DEI is not a trend but essential to a profitable and nomination-filled future.

The Creative Arts and Governors Gala ceremonies will occur over two nights on Sept. 7-8. The 76th Primetime Emmy Awards will air on ABC on Sunday, Sept. 15.

Top 4 projected winning leaders (series): ‚ÄúSh≈çgun‚Äù (12); ‚ÄúThe Bear‚Äù (11); ‚ÄúBaby Reindeer‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Crown‚Äù and ‚ÄúFallout‚Äù (5); ‚ÄúHacks,‚Äù ‚ÄúRipley‚Äù and ‚ÄúSaturday Night Live‚Äù (4)

Top 5 projected winning leaders (networks): FX (27); Netflix (23); Max (12); NBC (6); ABC and CBS (5)
